Message.Title: Ouya CEO Reveals Plans For Yearly Hardware Refreshes
Message.Msg: "Nvidia has a team dedicated to the OUYA console" "marketplace will be packed full of games at launch." And those Android games will run on Shield... !! --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This should be a little annoying to customers who have been eying the Android-powered OUYA console. Company CEO Julie Uhrman confirmed with Joystiq that unlike the traditional console that sees a new hardware set every five to seven years, OUYA plans to take the mobile route and release a new console every year. That's right: the OUYA you purchase in June will be obsolete this time next year. "Our strategy is very much similar to the mobile strategy," she said. "There will be a new OUYA every year. There will be an OUYA 2 and an OUYA 3. We'll take advantage of faster, better processors, take advantage of prices falling. So if we can get more than 8 GB of flash in our box, we will." At $100 a pop, buying a new OUYA every year doesn't seem quite so drastic compared to tablet, smartphone and even console prices. And if anything, the older models will make great media players on other HDTVs in the house once they've been replaced with new models as the primary Android gaming machine. And like Google Play and Amazon's Appstore, all games will be linked to the user, not the machine. They'll also be backward compatible so that you don't have to keep buying the same titles over and over. On a performance level, Uhrman said that Nvidia has a team dedicated to the OUYA console for getting the Tegra 3 running at optimal levels. The quad-core A9-based chip is clocked at 1.6 GHz and backed by 1 GB of RAM, 8 GB of internal storage (or 5 Gameloft games), 802.11 b/g/n connectivity, Bluetooth and HDMI output. It won't have a rechargeable battery, but instead will plug into the wall like every other living room console. The first wave of OUYA consoles will head out to the Kickstarter backers in March followed by a full-blown public release in June at retailers like Best Buy, GameStop, Target and Amazon. Additional controls will also be made available, costing $49.99 per unit. Uhrman also said the OUYA's marketplace will be packed full of games at launch.

Topic.Title: The growth of the chromebook market

Message.Msg: Moronsavin, Seriously, there is no reason to mess your khakis...I have no doubt that you've been tweaking batch files, maybe even tossed together a basic program or two, possibly dating back to am era in computing when 5 1/4 floppys were all the rage. Now that being said, I will conced my professional career hasn't transcended that many decades. However, and I do have to give you kudos for using the term, I am not a hand waiver (lol) by profession, and more importantly that doesn't change the fact that you are glorified pc repair man. The evolutionary precursor to the geek squad if you will... :) You don't have to state that my retort is wasted on you - your deluded and evasive responses have clearly demonstrate that. I NEVER WROTE THAT HT IS NOT SMT. Again, what I stated was HT was and said HT is not the same as a physical core but instead is a virtualized core. I was very detailed in my description of HT and never once did I state it wasn't an SMT implementation - despite the parallelism occurring at the instruction level? By the way guess which architecture (RISC or CISC) was the first to implement a superscalar architecture? Heres a hint... it wasn't x86! Now just as an added bonus do you (mr pc repairman) know how intel achieved this (going superscalar on the x86)....?? (cue theme from jeopardy) - what is micro-ops translation. Yes sir by translating those big bad complex disc instructions to more atomic, essentially RISC like, instructions. There you have it - not only is HT not the same as a second core but in order for x86 to implement it and virtualize a second core it has to transform itself into a RISC processor (sort of :p) first. Now, do YOU still want to argue with me about scale? As for performance as I've said lets wait until we have a true compatible piece of silicon. There are so many things inherently wrong with this test. The least of which of is running a parellel workload (EP is the one you called out i assume as it was the one that didnt require any communication between cores) designed to work on an isolated system on a distrubted one. There are inate effeciencies when you run this all on the same piece of slicon and to make the assumption that just because each baord ran its own copy of code then its the same as if all the cores were on the same piece of silicon is rather naive and honestly moronic. if this were the case then why didnt they just measure the equivalent number of atom boards in the same manner - after all they are similar class and core configuration - btw arm crushed it in compute per watt. For one thing although you may be running indepent copies of the EP code you are also running independent copies of the os. In those terms the intel proc had a 6x advantage. I can go on and on but im tired, however, if you reply to this, I will be happy to go into more technical detail as to why the phoronix benchmark was more of an exercise in 'can do' than apples to apples comparison. From the load to how they measured power draw. I might even pull one of our veteran EE's into this (the one who use to build processors) just for fun. :)

Topic.Title: The growth of the chromebook market

Message.Msg: Stupidagain, ] You are still going down diversionary strawman routes to avoid data that does not back up your theoretical ramblings. If it makes you feel better ignore the cluster and just take a native dual or quad benchmark of your own choosing and multiply it up, I gave 3 links which included an A15 test too. Find me some data that proves a theoretical 16 core A9 or A16 will have a material impact on a Xeon server chip in some important metric to server users. p.s. you still don't understand my computing experience. I have had nothing to do with PC maintenance. I have designed, wrote and tuned company's core business computer systems that actually run their businesses like their financials, stock control/replenishment and other bespoke essential business functions. Started in Cobol and now on Oracle with various OLTP/DWH languages in addition. Worked on Mainframes, VAX, Alphas and Superdomes and tuned the enterprise servers running all the computer systems not just the ones I designed and wrote. If you think that equates to a PC repairman you are even more stupid than I thought.

Message.Title: NVIDIA Tegra 4: the future of mobile computing?
Message.Msg: A balanced article from ITProPortal SOURCE: itproportalDOTcom/2013/02/11/nvidia-tegra-4-future-mobile-computing/ Last month, Nvidia surprised roughly no-one by announcing the successor to Tegra 3, the processor at the heart of the Asus Transformer line of tablets, the Google Nexus 7, Microsoft’s Surface, HTC’s One X and a whole line-up of Android smartphones and slates. At the end of this month, we expect to see the Tegra 4 appearing in new smartphones and tablets at Mobile World Conference 2013, potentially including HTC’s rumoured flagship 5in phone, the M7, and tablets from Asus, Toshiba and Vizio. It’s unquestionably one of 2013’s most exciting mobile chips. There’s also no doubt of its power. Where the Tegra 3 was built around quad-core ARM Cortex A9 architecture, Tegra 4 brings us a quad-core architecture based on ARM’s next-generation Cortex A15 design. A shift from TSMC’s 40nm LPG process to 20nm LPC helps Tegra 4 reach 1.8GHz – 200MHz faster than Tegra 3 – without blowing heat and power budgets. Like Tegra 3, Tegra 4 features a fifth companion core for background tasks, though again it’s moved from A9 to A15, but now supports dual-channel DDR3 RAM. Nvidia estimates that Tegra 4 is about 20 times faster than Tegra 2 and six times faster than Tegra 3; that’s not to be sniffed at. Admittedly, there are some disappointments. In terms of GPU power, Tegra 4 is a big step up from Tegra 3. With six Vec4 vertex units and four 3-deep Vec4 pixel units, for a total of 72 cores, Tegra 4 has six times the number of Arithmetic Logic Units (ALUs) dedicated to graphics of Tegra 3, all running at a higher clock speed than they did on Tegra 3. In desktop PC terms, it’s close in power to the GeForce 7 series, including the RSX chip found in Sony’s PlayStation 3. However, those expecting a more efficient unified shader architecture, as found in the GeForce 8 line and upwards, not to mention a shared architecture with Kepler, may be underwhelmed. Tegra 4’s GPU architecture is understood to be an extension of Tegra 3’s with key enhancements, rather than a wholesale reinvention/...... _______ Note: The "criticism of non-unified shaders in Tegra 4 has been addressed by NV management. It is a tradeoff for greater energy efficiency, rather than an issue of technical feasibility.

Message.Title: Project shield comes next quarter to Europe,US and Canada
Message.Msg: and rest of world...Project Shield: Turbo charged gaming handheld coming to the UK!Are you itching to getting your hands on Nvidia’s lightning fast gaming handheld, Project Shield? You won’t have to wait too long, as the company is moving fast to get the console to the UK as soon as possible. Best known for its graphics cards, Nvidia surprised many at CES last month with its clamshell gaming console that can play Android games and stream even demanding PC games. While the console is set to hit the US and Canada between April and June, the company is keen to get the handheld out the door and into gamers’ hands worldwide. Wikipad gaming tablet slims down: Seven inch PS Vita rival on the way! According to Nvidia’s director of product marketing Jason Paul, the company wants to sprint to get it into Europe and Asia. “Since the announcement we’ve had people knocking on our door. So there’s interest in distributing the product. Shield is targeting Android and PC gamers, so we are looking for people who can sell into that market.” Game systems live and die by the number of games available for them, and that depends on the numbers sold – a real chicken and egg situation Nvidia will be keen to solve quickly with a global release it seems – so look out for Project Shield on these shores soon.

Message.Title: Apple has made the transition from "growth" to "value" stock
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Barrons this morning By Tiernan Ray Here are some things going on this morning in your world of tech: Shares of Apple (AAPL) are up $7.31, or 1.5%, at $482.29as the Street continues to contemplate the prospect of enhanced payouts raised by David Einhorn’s protests last week. On Sunday, ISI Group’s Brian Marshall reiterated a Strong Buy rating on the stock and a $600 price target, saying he’d spoken with AAPL’s CFO (Peter Oppenheimer) this past Friday and found the conversation helpful “we are starting to field calls from “smart money” investors who are building positions in AAPL at current levels based on the belief that: 1) AAPL has *already* made the transition to a “value play” (from a growth story), and 2) a favorable capital allocation update will be the next catalyst for share.” Jim Stewart was on CNBC this morning to talk about the failure of the Apple bulls, as laid out in his “Common Sense” column from Friday in The New York Times. “I went back to look at the absolute peak, it was overwhelmingly Buy and Strong Buy. I was seeing the same old herd instinct all over again. There’s this trading desk problem, if you put out a buy, everyone can go buy and generate selling commissions.” In case you missed it, Bloomberg’s Peter Burrows writes that the drop in Apple’s profit margin to 39% from 45% a year earlier means that “Unless Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook unveils a revolutionary new gadget with premium pricing, Apple shares will remain under pressure.” Cook is scheduled to speak at the Goldman Sachs tech conference, tomorrow afternoon, at 1:15 pm, Pacific Time.

Message.Msg: no, i'm not. you're looking at yahoo's keys statistics page which only looks at cash & equivalents. you need to look at their balance sheet. They do the same thing MSFT does, and keep the majority of their cash in what are considered "long term investments" by GAAP accounting, but are actually highly liquid investments. That's why you hear analysts and more informed investors quoting the $137B in total cash figure. My numbers reflect that.

Topic.Title: You may not know if Google and Microsoft passed on Tegra 4 for NEW Tablets but Nvidia knows?

Message.Msg: Last year, on many occasions, Jen Hsun openly expressed surprise in Microsoft choosing Tegra 3 in Surface RT. NV was not exactly consulted nor informed much earlier than the general public. In fact, in January 2012, QC's marketing department put out a Win 8 on ARM campaign (that was the term used then) implying that Snapdragon S4 was the "designated" one - it probably was, only that QC couldn't step up to the plate with the appropriate qualifying drivers. Even as early as in June, 2012, Engadget and Anandtech published big "hands on" articles heralding the arrival of a new age (S4 in Win Surface leading the charge) which, embarrassingly, did NOT happen. As NVDA longs, we need to be more discriminating about QC's marketing rhetoric, both directly and thru third parties, as well as the paid to write/talk, high-profile tech pundits like A and E - in some ways they are only a shade better than the hired bashers on this board, in that they are more technically knowledgeable. Still they likely got paid to write what they did.

Topic.Title: NVIDIA Tegra 4: the future of mobile computing?

Message.Msg: These decisions were not always made on technical merits. In the case of MS and QC, Microsoft, like Google, would like to play the musical chairs and spread its gospel around - well you can't really fault them for this - and MS specially needs QC chips for its Win Phones. Besides technical merits and business strategy, there is also the image issue - in that MS considers QC its equal in bigness. Ballmer probably fantasizes a similar duopoly with Qualcomm just like the fading Wintel empire.

Message.Title: Good luck into earnings, longs

I assume we'll all be here to discuss the earnings call :-) Let's hope that Jen and his team: - Continued to take market share from AMD in GPUs - Scored some nice design wins with Tegra 3/4 in China phones - Nailed a high profile tablet design or two with Tegra 4 - Saw a recovery in the workstation market + strong ramp in Tesla Most of all, let's hope Q1 guide is strong.

Topic.Title: Good luck into earnings, longs

Message.Msg: I wouldn't count on Jen Hsun discuss details of design wins with names and dates and all. They rarely did; most legitimate companies do not discuss the business plans of their customers. (You could lose this customer or be sued later if your partner changes its mind). You should know that - if not, then you should as a regular SA writer.

Topic.Title: Good luck into earnings, longs

However, I doubt you would learn too many specifics....not smart to show your hand in such a highly competitive space.

Message.Title: GTC Is Expanding
Message.Msg: GTC is evolving and expanding. Like previous years, GTC 2013 will continue to deliver the same great content for domain scientists and researchers, but will also focus on the dramatic changes happening in computer graphics, cloud graphics, game development, and mobile computing, and how the GPU is central to innovation in all areas. GTC IS DESIGNED FOR Computational Researchers and Application Developers in HPC pursuing the latest in scientific discovery and innovation in life sciences, oil & gas, defense, finance, and more. By attending GTC, you'll discover convincing content focused on best practices and trends, tools, research findings, and next generation products. Learn more. Computational Researchers and Application Developers in HPC Designers & Engineering Workgroup Managers in Manufacturing virtually prototyping products using the latest 3D design, visualization and simulation tools in order to speed up their workflow. By attending GTC, you'll discover a broad perspective of all the latest design techniques and tools available. Learn more. Designers & Engineering Workgroup Managers in Manufacturing Visual Effects Artists & Independent Creatives in the Media & Entertainment Industry creating video, animations, 3D, and motion graphics content. By attending GTC, you'll discover how GPU technology helps speed production times and helps produce state-of-the-art effects. Learn more. Visual Effects Artists & Independent Creatives in the Media & Entertainment Industry Cloud Developers, Enterprise CIOs, and Data Center Management moving to a cloud-based virtualized computing infrastructure or developing new SaaS offerings. By attending GTC, you'll discover perspectives on the best interactive desktop experiences only enabled by GPUs, and visibility into the future of cloud graphics. Learn more. Cloud Developers, Enterprise CIOs, and Data Center Management Game and App Developers in Mobile Computing needing to stay up-to-date on the latest development tools and techniques, technology roadmaps, and ROI business trends. By attending GTC, you'll gain a valuable perspective into the convergence of mobile across verticals, and discover accelerated mobile application and game development techniques for faster time-to-market cycles. Learn more. Game and App Developers in Mobile Computing PC & Console Game Developers creating next generation games in a highly competitive market place. By attending GTC, you'll discover world-class content showcasing state-of-the-art development techniques and tools. Learn more. PC & Console Game Developers Startups and Investors interested in promoting and discovering promising companies developing disruptive technologies revolutionizing the computer industry. By attending GTC's Emerging Companies Summit, you'll watch CEO presentations, see amazing product demos, and have valuable opportunities for networking among companies, investors, key decision makers, and leading consumer, business, and trade press. Learn more. ______________________________________________________________________ 1/3rd is on Gaming....Back to the Future
